matching.title: Matching

doc.title: Instructions for use
doc.p1: This software allows you to do bipartite matching on two data tables, the objective is to be able to obtain pairs (each member of which comes from a different table) and which respect certain constraints. The goal is also to be able to easily orient the matching using a DSL (Domain Specific Language). The DSL present in this software makes it possible to write constraints that must be satisfied for a pair to be considered viable.
doc.p2: Thus the ultimate goal of this software is to allow focusing on the matching policy and to launch a matching algorithm which will respect this policy. Once launched, the matching is done in a few seconds where a manual matching would take several hours.
doc.p3: Each mentee and mentor table must be imported in CSV format and with a semicolon separator. Each table must be encoded in UTF-8 format. If you're having trouble encoding your data tables from Excel, here's what to do.
doc.li1: Make sure your column names are unique within the same data table.
doc.li2: Export your tables in CSV format using the separator ";" (semicolon)
doc.li3: Encode your CSV files in UTF-8 format with the free software on Windows: Notepad ++
doc.li4: Once the tables have been imported into the software, specify the type of each column using the edit button in the "tables" page, you have two choices:
doc.li7: Ex: The age of mentors will be of type Number while the location of their workplace will be of type Text.
doc.nb1: NB: This step is crucial for the proper functioning of the algorithm.
doc.p4: The constraints are constructed as follows:
doc.li8: There are two key words: "mentee" and "mentor"
doc.li9: To refer to a column found in the mentee table and whose name is for example "Column 1", you must write "mentee.COLONNE_1". The column name is slightly changed for DSL: all letters are uppercase and spaces are replaced by an underscore.
doc.li10: You can then use comparison operators to write your first constraint: mentee.AGE <mentor.AGE
doc.li11: You can also use logical and computational operators to make your constraint more complex: mentee.AGE <mentor.AGE and mentee.JOB_LEVEL + 2 <mentor.JOB_LEVEL
doc.li12: The comparison operators are: <, <=,>,> =, =, not (ie is not equal to)
doc.li14: The logical operators are: and, or
doc.li15: You can use parentheses for priorities.
doc.p5: You can rename and save your project. By convention, a project whose name is "My mentoring project" will be saved in the form "mon_projet_de_mentoring.bmatch", the bmatch extension is specific to this software.
doc.p6: To save your current project make sure to dedicate a folder to it on your computer and save regularly to this location.
